hackathon-description-text: MHacks is the largest hackathon in the world, run exclusively for students, by students. We bring together the smartest people from around the world for 36 hours of incredible hacking.
hackathon-eligibility:
- Teams can have a maximum of 4 members
- All members must be registered and physically present at MHacks
hackathon-rules:
- YOU MUST BE AT MHACKS TO WORK ON A PROJECT FOR SUBMISSION
- Fresh code! You cannot work on your project before the event begins.
- You cannot steal another team's source code.
- The decision of judges is final for determining prizes and awards.
- Please comply with all instructions from MHACKS organizers.
hackathon-requirements: Build something awesome. All platforms accepted.
hackathon-description-header: Looking for the most recent MHacks? : http://mhacks8.devpost.com/

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best use of Twilio API - Lego Mindstorms EV3

hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best use of TellApart

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: A priority review of the 2014 Thiel Fellowship application
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Thiel Fellowship "Under 20" Prize - All team members must be under the age of 20

hackathon-prizes.prize-content: NeuroSky Mindwaves - Control apps on your computer using your brain waves.
hackathon-prizes.prize-title: Best Finance Related App - Benzinga Pro
Best use of Point.io

hackathon-judging-criteria.judging-criterion: Is the hack practical? Is it something people would actually use? Does it fulfill a real need people have?
Is the hack more than just another generic social/mobile/local app? Does it do something entirely novel, or at least take a fresh approach to an old problem?
Is the hack technically interesting or difficult? Is it just some lipstick on an API, or were there real technical challenges to surmount?
Is the hack usable in its current state? Is the user experience smooth? Does everything appear to work? Is it well designed?
